problem:
Let $x$ be a real number such that $\sec x - \tan x = 2$. Then $\sec x + \tan x =$


$\textbf{(A)}\ 0.1 \qquad  \textbf{(B)}\ 0.2 \qquad  \textbf{(C)}\ 0.3 \qquad  \textbf{(D)}\ 0.4 \qquad  \textbf{(E)}\ 0.5$

solutions.Solution 1 (Fastest): $(\sec x - \tan x)(\sec x + \tan x) = \sec^{2} x - \tan^{2} x = 1$, so $\sec x + \tan x = \boxed{\textbf{(E)}\ 0.5}$.
solutions.Solution 2 (Alternate, Slightly Longer):
Note that $\sec x - \tan x = (1-\sin x)/\cos x$ and $\sec x + \tan x = (1+\sin x)/\cos x$. Let $(1+\sin x)/\cos x = y$. Multiplying, we get $(1-\sin^{2}x)/\cos^{2}x = 1$.Then, $2y = 1$. $\sec x + \tan x =  \boxed{\textbf{(E)}\ 0.5}$. ~songmath20
